Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Computational Modeling of the Effects of Climate Change and Land Acquisition on Household Dynamics in Southern Ethiopia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The current surge in large-scale land acquisition in developing countries is a complex socio-natural systems problem that also is emerging as a global policy issue. Significant tracts of land are being leased to agribusiness enterprises based in both poor and industrialized countries. The resulting expansion of large-scale land acquisition contributes to the rural economy by creating jobs, developing infrastructure, and transferring technologies. It also negatively affects rural households, however, because most large-scale land acquisition (combined with ongoing effects of climate change) affects the pastoralist livelihoods of rural people by limiting their access to resources, eventually leading them to dispossession and displacement. Although agent-based models previously have been used for modeling complexity in human-environmental systems, the influence of large actors and their interactions with local households have not been addressed and remain poorly understood. This doctoral dissertation research project will apply an agent-based modeling simulation approach that explicitly represents the main actors (enterprises, households, and institutions) to understand their interactions and dynamics with the environment in the South Omo region in southwestern Ethiopia. The doctoral student will integrate methods from spatial agent-based modeling and GIS along with social network analysis and quantitative analysis. The agent simulation model will use quantitative and qualitative socioeconomic data, with explicit spatial referencing based on geographic data, thereby enabling agents to interact in environments resembling the real world. He also will use a participatory modeling strategy that involves consultation before, during, and after each stage of modeling with local stakeholders, such as agribusiness enterprises, government officials, and local community households.

The project will enhance understanding regarding dynamic interactions between rural households and enterprises; the consequences of different actions of actors on the land and reciprocal feedbacks; and the impact of climate change on ecosystems and local communities. By using a complex system approach, the project will contribute fundamental new understanding regarding the nonlinear dynamic interaction of human and environment components at multiple spatial and temporal scales. The project will enhance current scientific knowledge about human-environment systems by explicitly modeling the dynamics of heterogeneous actors, institutions, and their environments. The participatory modeling approach will expose a broad spectrum of constituencies to scientific research on complex socio-environmental systems. The project also will provide new, scientifically informed perspectives for the science-policy debate on this significant development issue. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How are individual herders and farmers in developing countries affected when large-scale land leases and industrial agricultural management changes take place in areas previously occupied by traditional communities? How do changes in climate patterns affect agropastoralists and others who live in those areas? What happens to indigenous communities when compound changes in land use and climate change both occur simultaneously? How do scientists assess the potential for such disasters and possible humanitarian crises? Many areas of the developing world, in Africa, Latin America, and Asia, are affected by these situations, mainly due to recent government policies that lease large areas of traditional lands to industrial-scale agricultural enterprises, often foreign-based and operated. Analyzing these situations poses major scientific challenges, given the large number of variables, different ecosystems, and variety of stakeholders involved, in addition to complex interactions that need to be represented---especially between human and biophysical systems that work in a coupled way, as humans do with climate, especially in developing areas where weather matters greatly.

This doctoral dissertation study examined the region of southern Ethiopia in the African continent, known as South Omo Zone, to investigate these questions pertaining to land use, climate change, government policies, and effects on traditional human communities living in those areas. The region was chosen because it represents an excellent example of the complex set of situations described above, including the ecosystems that lie to the north of Lake Turkana in Southern Ethiopia, traditional communities of nomadic and semi-nomadic people (over a dozen different ethnic groups, including Aari, Male, Hamer, among the largest), ongoing climate change (droughts and precipitation patterns), large agricultural companies, and government agencies producing separate policies with different objectives, such as leasing lands, mitigating climate change, and assisting local populations. The result is a highly complex situation similar to that observed in other regions of the world.

The main results of the study demonstrate how 1) climate change has measurable effects on human communities, in terms of inducing socioeconomic stress sometimes leading to displacement; 2) land use change caused by leases of large tracks of formerly traditional grazing and agropastoral areas has similar effects in terms of causing stress and potential displacement; 3) the compound of effect of both climate change and land use change can have devastating consequences on human communities; and 4) government policies aimed at disaster mitigation can have positive effects, but only if designed and implemented in ways that impede large-scale land-use change.

The main scientific tool that was used to conduct this study is a type of advanced computer simulation model called an "agent-based" model (ABM) in computational social science, or "individual-based" model (IBM) in ecology, and "multi-agent" system (MAS) in computer science. The model specifically created for this study is called OmoLand, named after the South Omo Zone of Ethiopia, and it represents the real-world details of a geographic area extending approximately 2.3 million hectares with arid and semi-arid climate, occupied by 125,009 households representing a total population of just over half a million inhabitants. The OmoLand model was created using a scientific simulation toolkit called MASON (Multi-Agent Simulator of Networks and Neighborhoods), invented at George Mason University by a team led by computer science professor Sean Luke and co-funded by the Mason Center for Social Complexity, directed by professor Claudio Cioffi-Revilla (dissertation advisor in this project).
